awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multiscale Study of the Structure and Dynamics of Nanoparticle-Protein Coronae
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal: 1553945
PI: Ding, Feng    

With the rapid development of nanotechnology, engineered nanoparticles (NPs) may be released to the environmental and biological systems either purposely or accidentally. With many proteins enriched in the environmental and biological media as the functional building blocks, they can be absorbed onto the NP surface, forming the so-called NP-protein corona. It is the protein coronae rather than the original NPs that are "seen" by cells and tissues and subsequently determine the biological and/or pathological functions of these released NPs. The objective of this proposal is to develop and apply state-of-the-art computer simulation methods to understand the fundamental aspects of the corona formation and to determine the physical and chemical properties of NPs that dictate the protein absorption. The obtained knowledge will help guide the design of novel NPs that promotes the intended biological functions and prevents the unintended pathological responses, enabling the "safe-by-design" to the broad scientific and engineering community for modeling and predicting corona formation and rapid risk assessment of NP exposures. 

In this CAREER proposal, the PI proposes to apply the multiscale discrete molecular dynamics (DMD) methodology to characterize the structure and dynamics of NP-protein corona and to identify the physicochemical determinants of the NP-protein interactions. The objective of this research will be accomplished by pursuing the following specific aims: 1) Develop NP models and their interactions with biomolecules for DMD simulations; 2) Uncover the physicochemical determinants of NP-protein binding; 3) Characterize the structure and dynamics of protein aggregation in the corona; and 4) Extend the research and education in classroom and laboratory more broadly to other education and scientific research community. The developed and validated computational methodology will be shared with the broad scientific research communities. The proposed research projects will uncover the structural and dynamic properties of NP-protein corona at the molecular and atomic level and determine the physicochemical determinants of the molecular complex formation. The obtained results from the proposed mechanistic studies will be pivotal in designing more efficient and safe NPs with optimal properties to promote intended biological functions and minimize the pathological implications of NP exposure. 

Broader impacts of this proposal include the sustainable development of nanotechnology and improves applications of nanomedicine. Funding of this research will also support students training at the interfaces of physics, material science, biology, and environmental science and engineering, update physics curriculum to reflect the current trend in science, and increase the diversity of physics education and research. The proposed research will develop and validate critical predictive tools to effectively and efficiently model the nano-bio interface, which can be used for engineering NPs with novel biological functions as well as for NP risk assessment. In addition, easy accessibility and enhanced usability of the developed tools will benefit the broad science and engineering community working in the field.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER project aimed to develop and apply state-of-the-art computer simulation methods to understand fundamental interactions at the interface between engineered nanoparticles (NPs) and biomolecules in the environmental and biological milieu, namely the formation of NP-protein coronae. Under this support, the PI laboratory has already explanded the multiscale discrete molecular dynamics (DMD, a rapid and accurate molecular dynamics algorithm pioneered by the PI to study biomolecules) methods to characterize the structures and dynamics of NP-protein corona and identify the driving forces for NP-protein binding. Specifically, the PI lab has developed atomistic models of many nanoparticles from metals and metal oxides to polymers such as nanoplastics. The PI integrated these NP models into DMD simulations of biomolecules, including lipids, proteins, and nucleotides. Using the developed computational tools, the PI lab has uncovered the physicochemical determinants of NP-protein binding, and revealed that the complementarity of shapes, interactions, and also dynamics between NPs and proteins drives their binding. The predictive power of the developed DMD methodology has been repeatedly validated experimentally to accurately model the structure and dynamics of the corona at the atomic and molecular levels. These computational tools are freely available at PI?s group website to other researchers working in the field. These obtained molecular insights at the Nano-Bio interface could facilitate ?safe-by-design? nanotechnology for biocompatibility and sustainability, and importantly laid the foundation for the PI?s pioneering works of mitigating amyloid toxicity with designed nanoparticles, and also the discovery of molecular mechanisms governing nanoparticle-induced endothelial leakiness - a novel paracellular pathway of nanoparticles to cross biological barriers.

 

The PI extended the concept of NP-protein corona to explore novel nanomedicine approach to mitigate amyloid aggregation and toxicity. Amyloidosis refers to the aberrant aggregation of proteins and peptides into fibrils, constituting insoluble deposits in human tissues - e.g., the hallmarks of plaques in Alzheimer's disease, Lewy bodies in Parkinson's disease, and islet amyloids in type 2 diabetes. With deep insights of NP-protein corona, the PI was the first in the field to systematically inhibit amyloid aggregation with engineered nanoparticles, which leads to the emerging field of anti-amyloid nanomedicine. The PI lab uncovered the molecular mechanism of many anti-amyloid nanoparticles and revealed the principle of mitigating amyloid toxicity - i.e., minimizing the population of toxic oligomers during early amyloid aggregation. For example, the PI and collaborators coated gold nanoparticles with a milk protein, β casein, and showed that the synthesized NP was able to inhibit the development of Alzheimer?s disease symptoms in a zebrafish model. As the leader in this emerging research area, the PI and the experimental collaboration team has been invited to write several reviews and perspectives in high-impact journals.

 

The PI uncovered the molecular mechanism of nanoparticle-induced endothelial leakiness (NanoEL), a novel paracellular pathways for nanoparticles to cross biological barriers.  In NanoEL, nanoparticles disrupt the vascular endothelial cadherin (VE-cadherin) junctions of apposing endothelial cells, causing actin reorganization and transient gap formation among the impacted cells and tissues, different from the classical enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect. The PI lab uncovered the molecular mechanisms of NP-binding induced dissociation of VE-cadherin and offered a new framework for quantifying NanoEL in silico, in vitro, and in vivo. In particular, the PI lab demonstrated that nanoplastics - e.g., polystyrene and poly(methyl methacrylate) - could induce NanoEL and cause damage to the vascular endothelial cadherin junctions. The pioneering work opened up vast avenues for investigating the behavior and biological effects of nanoplastics, which may offer crucial insights for guiding innovations towards a sustainable plastics industry and environmental remediation.

 

The PI also integrated state-of-the-art research into education, training next generation scientists and engineers to meet major challenges of the 21st century. The PI developed a new graduate elective course with the focus of nanotechnology and nano-bio interface. The PI also used the research results as the source materials for classroom examples, reading assignment, and term projects in the teaching of traditional Physics core courses. In addition to the conventional training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, the funding also allowed the PI to offer research opportunities to high school and undergraduate students. All the undergrads presented their research at workshops or professional conferences, and some of them were able to publish co-authored papers with their research in the lab. Most of these trainees continued to their education and research career in STEM.
